As I logged into Steam, there was an update. An update for a specific game, Dead Rising 2.
I clicked on the game in my library, having several questions. It was a surprise, given that they seemed to have abandoned it. And there, in the cold, dead, newsfeed, was a fresh one. A new article had come out on that day. An article announcing...
GFWL was finally wiped off of the face of Dead Rising 2.
As this news was bestowed upon me, I stopped. Looking away from my monitor and into the distant, purple sky.
 It's over. " I softly whispered. " It's finally over.  ""

reviewText:
This game is fantastic and quickly became one of my favorite games of all time. If you like open-world games with a sense of humor, and you want to plow through thousands of enemies using all sorts of crazy improvised weapons, this is the game for you. This is one of the last games by Keiji Inafune before he left Capcom.

However, it requires you to create and sign in with a Games for Windows Live account. In order to save your game, you need to be signed in and connected at all times. This is a real problem. I can no longer get this game to even run, because the Games for Windows Live installer crashes on my Windows 8.1 system. The only way around this would be to either download a pirated copy that removes Games for Windows Live or play it on a console. Either way, I wouldn't be able to play the game with my friends, which is the best part of the game.

Worse yet, Microsoft is shutting down its Games for Windows Live service, making this game essentially useless. The good news is, Capcom has announced that they will be patching it to remove Games for Windows Live. As I write this review, Capcom has yet to do so. I can only hope they stay true to their word. Once again, this is one of the best games ever.

reviewText:
Five years and two platforms later, still a fantastic, unique title.

+ Story is interesting, albeit a tad contrived. Servicable voice acting, decent plot and a good protagonist make uncovering the next story event something to look forward to.
+ Lively, well developed characters.
+ Myriad of fun and effective weapons. Combine two weapons into one of extreme power. Combo weapons are creative and worth the hassle.
+ Leveling up your character gives rewarding incentive to do some sandbox and replays.
+ Fantastically recorded and generated sound assets.
+ Fortune City is a colorful, enjoyable map with plenty of fun and surprises.
+ Zombies are dismembered in satisfying, dynamic ways.
+ Visuals are obviously dated but serviceable.
+ Decent amount of PC options. Controls are relatively problem free. Not a Mad Max quality port, but certainly a giant leap from something Arkham Knight quality.
+ Co-op can ease up more difficult missions and add substantial enjoyment to the slaughter.
+ Vehicles are a great transportation/murder tool, even if the controls can be a bit over/under compensating.

- The timer is the biggest controversy of this game. I personally hate being paced, stressed, and rushed. The only reason I reccomend this game is because you can disable/slow the timer with mods and trainers. The timer adds a decent challenge to the game but leaves little time for fun screwing around or side missions.
- Competetive online is dead, but it was never really all that" in the first place. Fairly generic "American Gladiator"-esque challenges that involve zombie death.
- Side missions; particularly the survivor escorts
date: are repetetive and pretty boring. Survivors can slow you down and become a time wasting liability.\n- Although the "psychopath" boss fights are memorable and contain great characters
recommended: they are rather annoying and dependant on your level rather than your skill and adaptability. They often boil down to the same "dodge this then hit me" formula.\n- Some combat mechanics wear thin quick and become a chore. Shaking your mouse in a QTE to shed a grappling zombie (which happens OFTEN)
hoursPlayed: getting knocked flat on your â™¥â™¥â™¥ and stunned by almost all human attacks
voteText: stopping to cough sporatically when the later introduced enemy attacks you.\n- Normal
helpfulPercent: non-combo weapons feel a bit underpowered for the most part. Firearms have their damage heavily reduced against human enemies for no explained reason. Uncombined melee and throwable weapons break very quickly and yield very little experience.\n\nOverall
votesHelpful: Chuck Greene's a pretty cool guy who makes pretty cool weapons and kills zombies in pretty cool ways in a pretty cool set-piece. The only overbearing cons are the timer which can be circumvented via mods and the lousy side-missions which are totally optional. Picked up for about $7 which justifies almost thirty hours of play."

reviewText:
You can create a rocket launcher made out of pipes and fireworks, and boxing gloves with knifes attached to them, what's not to love?

Dead rising 2 is a  good zombie slaugthering time, even with it's annoyences and issues.

The game takes place a few years after the first one and follows chuck greene, a motorcycle rider/father, who is framed for the zombie outbreak on fortune city. Story is fairly decent, but it's not the game's strongest aspect. There is multiple endings, but ending A and S are the only ones worth getting.

Describing the type of game dead rising is, is rather tricky since it's in a league of it's, however what I can call it is that it's a beat em up hack n slash third person shooting open world rpg, or you can just call it an action rpg.

Combat is slow and kind of annoying, but somehow in the end it's so fun slicing and bashing zombies. You can use anything as a weapon from knifes,guns (which are quite fun to use), brooms, to wheelchairs even. However each item breaks, which makes the game kind of refreshing.

One of the elements of the game that makes it so much fun is the combo cards, which allow you to take 2 items you find. You need to go to a maintenance room for it.

There is an rpg element in the sense that you will level up with PP. How do you get PP? Kill Kill and Kill, and also completing side missions which involves Rescuing survivors(which is kind of annoying, but tolerable if you find the leadership magazine) and fighting psychopaths(Optional boss battles that are generally enjoyable to fight).

the game also has a Timer which will turn a lot of people off....on the first playthrough, on the 2nd since you are at a higher level it's no big deal.

Dead rising 2 may not be technically impressive, but the game is never afraid to show something visually appealing and the animations are fairly good.

Sound is good, the music is ranges from lounge music, rock, to atmospheric music which fits well with the goofy nature of the game.

Dead rising 2 may not appeal to everyone, but what it does it's does it quite well.

7/10

reviewText:
A bit about the game and developers.
Dead Rising 2 is a sequel to a zombie slaying game - Dead Rising. Dead Rising 2 is set a bit after Dead Rising, but has nothing to do with the original game. Dead Rising 2 has been developed by Blue Castle Games, and published by Capcom! It's funny how Capcom has so many well known zombie games...

About Gameplay.
Dead Rising 2 is an open world zombie survival game. In Dead Rising 2 you have couple of missions (one main mission and a lot of side missions) which you do not need to follow at all! You see, Dead Rising 2 is a game in which you can do almost anything. Grab a motorbike, put a chainsaw on it and run over zombies. Or grab a motorbike, put machine gun on it and kill more zombies! Or just run around with nothing but a blade in your hands, chopping down everything in your path. The ways you can kill this zombies are almost limitless!

What makes this game far better than the first one is co-op option! You can call a friend to play this game with you and destroy the zombies with you! It's very fun indeed! Imagine two motorbikes with chainsaws, just driving down the street, ending every single zombie's life that is currently present.  This game also gives you and ability to craft a weapon out of two other weapons. For example, with a broom and a machete you make something like a spear. With knife and boxing gloves you make razor claws. With nails and a baseball bat... Very deadly baseball bat! You get the point - it's extremely fun!

So, as I said, you can chose to do the mission or you could just chose to ignore it and have loads of fun in the game. The game has six different endings, which all happen with a reason. For example, if you do whole main mission and then chose option A on some point (i don't plan to give out any spoilers!) You'll get first and best ending. If you do main mission and chose option B, you'll get almost same thing as A case. Everything else is more or less failure.

The game also futures a four person co-op in which all you can do is drive around a small area on a motorcycle and kill tones and tones and tones of zombies. I can't tell you much about that because I never managed to get into a game. There are just not enough players that play it..

Graphic and Audio
Graphically speaking the game looks very very sweet. There's just enough blood, the zombies are quite detailed and everything seems in place. They could have added more different looking zombies though. Audio is very awesome and never gets too boring to listen to! It keeps changing as you enter stores, menu and so on and on. Only positive thoughts about Audio of this game!

Pros, cons and final grade.
Pros:
- Great co op fun.
- A lot of different clothing and weapons.
- Audio never gets boring.
- A lot of vehicles.
- You can keep on playing even if you decide not to do missions.

Cons:
- Main mission forces you to wait a long time before continuing the story..
- Only two people co op.
- No players so the 4 person co-op is impossible without friends.
- The game uses Games for Windows Live so it might become unplayable next year since GFWL is going down..

Overall grade: 8.5 / 10

Extra info: This is an amazing zombie killing game to pass the time. I really enjoyed playing it with a friend of mine, Mr.Trolla. Thank you for playing the game with me!

Thank you for reading my reviews! Don't forget that I'm usually posting new reviews on my blog weekly and you can check them out here:[/b] http://midnightwolfie.blogspot.com
Thank you![/b]

reviewText:
Difficulty: Just Right
The Bottom Line: Solid/Great
Score: 8.5

Note: This Game Been Tried Out And Reviewed In Offline Mode or On Another Steam Account And Or Consoles.

Dead Rising 2 stays true to the heart of Dead Rising 1.In other words, it feels and plays just like DR1 except it's, well, better. Pictures/camera have been replaced with custom weapons (much more fun),the AI has been drastically improved, the text size has been enlarged (finally),and no more annoying Otis.

Essentially,however,this game is a love/hate kind of deal. If you didn't like DR1, chances are,you're not going to like DR2.It follows the same overall system.You start out incredibly weak,you level up,psychopaths can be -extremely- hard,and dying is generally unforgiving (although this time around,having 3 save files really does help quite a bit).

Overall: If this doesn't sound like your thing, you'd best avoid the game. If you loved DR1, however, strap up and get ready for a satisfying, bloody, romp-ride. Well...that and coffee creamers. Plus: you will get to see my Twins.

reviewText:
I don't know about Windows 7 or below, but if you have Windows 8 then DO NOT BUY.  This game requires Games for Windows Live which has been a major pain to get working and set up.

The game installed so I tried to play it.  It required me to install Games for Windows but gave an error when it tried.  After searching through the internet for various fixes that did not help, I uninstalled the Games for Windows it tried to install.  I then installed it directly from the windows website.  It again did not work.  I uninstalled again and installed from the xbox website.  It now loaded up but gave me an error when trying to sign in with my windows live information.  The error is vague and I had to search it as well.  Apparently you have to manually login through the xbox website or through an xbox to accept the terms and conditions.  Games for windows is now working so I booted up Dead Rising.  Oh wait, there's an update needed for games for windows!  The update has failed 3 times now as it tries to shut down games for windows and instead just stalls and freezes.  Still trying...will update later...

TL:DR: Games for Windows is total garbage and ruins the experience of even TRYING to play this game on a PC.

Edit:  I can now get the game to start up and play, we'll see how it goes from here.  It is ridiculous that it took me over two hours to get it to run.  And this seems to be a known issue that a lot of people are having.  Nothing is simplified in fixing this issue and you have to research it.  I still advise to just buy it on console and not on PC.

reviewText: An improvement to the first game, now with an un-restricted co-op mode, allowing a friend to play through the entire game with you.  Like the first game, a vast chunk of your leveling up is still in saving many survivors littered throughout the place.  Though the survivors are not pants-on-head â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ when following you like in the first game, certain health inflated bosses are very hard to anticipate and before you know it, you'll have rounded up 6 different survivors, only to have a boss spring out of nowhere and mow them all down on the way back to the safe zone, watching helplessly in a stun lock by Capcom's love for over-exaggerated animations that can't be inturrupted.  The true fun in the game is combining weapons to make destructive, or hilarious (or both) combinations to aid your monster mash.  Overall, a fun game with replay value, but if you really want to explore, you better be prepared to let a few of those extra survivor cases just expire.

reviewText: There is frustration around every corner of this game.\nTo start off, you are not welcome to play this game at your own rate. It juxtaposes a Majora's Mask-Like mechanic around a leveling system. You level up and unlock recipies and special combat moves (most of which you can more easily unlock by inviting someone who has already beaten the game to your session) But you are also required to do the main missions in the time it gives you for each of them (Which ranges between more than enough time, to just enough time, to ridiculously slim time, to a lot of time, but you have to wait until the nick of time to actually show up, and that pisses me off the most) When you die or get a Game Over, you are given the option to either return to your last save, or the less popular option to keep all levels and experience in hand, but start the story over from the beginning. You have no other option, and your last save may as well be miles behind your grinding, and this is a VERY grindy game.\nNext, the fairness aspect is divided between the game and the missions. They worked hard to make the zombie combat realistic and fair, however the psychopath" bosses deal and take unreasonable amounts of damage

reviewText:
I played the original Dr on the 360, and in the usual capcom style- the game was punishing, frustrating, and highly addictive.

Dead Rising 2, like it's predecessor, focuses on placing you in a zombie  infested town with lots to do and only so much time to do it. The game is very effective in creating tension, and you will often feel conflicted by the decisions you make as you will not be able to do everything DR 2 has to offer on the first playthrough.

The game play is straightforward enough, you guide chuck Greene (motorcyclist extraordinaire) through a collection of zombie infested zones- each broken up by a 15 second load time, and along the way you will encounter bosses, looters, and survivors. Much of this content is optional, but you'll want to complete some of the side quests as they help Chuck level up, learn new moves, and become faster and stronger.

The story of Dead Rising 2 is good, if a little uninspired. You begin  at the end of a Terror is Reality" motorcycle show to find that fortune city is overrun by hordes of the undead. It's up to you to get chuck and his zombie infected daughter to a safe house that becomes home to you and your fellow survivors. The rest of the game's story feels more like a patchwork of cutscenes that feel like they sort of blend together
date: but do not feel directly linked to your actions or playstyle. Because you will only play about a third of the game'a content on a single playthrough
recommended: and because so much of that content is optional the story in Dead Rising 2 feels very loose and definitely takes a backseat to the game's truly excellent action.\n\nOn my first play Dead Rising 2 took me about 15 hours to complete. And with multiple playthroughs available there is easily plenty of zombie killing value here for your dollar. This is also a well optimized port that works well on lower end graphics cards. I had no trouble playing the game on a radeon R7 240. So if you are looking for a violent
hoursPlayed: zombie-infested romp look no further- Dead Rising 2 is here on pc and it's great!"

reviewText: Dead Rising 2 is an interesting game. The premise, while differing from the first one, presents the exact same kind of gameplay structure. You're thrust into a big locale filled with zombies from one end to the other, and your playground is stacked to the brim with items that you can pick up and either use as weapons or consume for health.\n\nOne big problem the game has that very ironically cripples the game's fun factor is the constantly running time, with relatively strict time limits placed on every mission in the game. From what I could glean, there is no way to turn this off. Even if they don't want to abandon the intentional rushed feeling of being stuck in a city filled with zombies, the time limit could make some concessions, considering it keeps running during almost all missions, even after you've initiated them, which might leave you to randomly fail a mission that, for example, involves carrying a wounded woman back to the safe house, a trial she survives with no problems if you don't waste time running to her rescue at the beginning of the mission, but for some reason the truth is lost forever" when you take time to make a few Painkillers and create some combo weapons beforehand and then go take her
date: and the timer runs out mid-mission.\n\nAnother gripe is the game's limited save system. This was a huge criticism levied at the first game

reviewText:
Don't listen to all these silly people complaing about GFWL not working. Yes it is a discontinued system, but when installed properly there's no problems playing the game. Since saying that isn't very helpful let me break it down

Here's what worked flawlessly for me on Windows 8.1 64 bit. I realize that this won't be neccesarry soon, but if you, like me, just bought it on sale for $5, you don't want to wait for this steamworks business.

Uninstall (if any) games for windows live things you have
I'm fairly sure you need the legacy .NET framework installed. On win 8 hit win+x then F to get to programs and features. Then turn windows features on and off
Check all the .NET framework boxes for 3.5 and 4.5, just to be safe.
I'm not sure where to find the current GFWL installer, but luckily I still have it from when I solved this trouble for one of the batman games, so I just made a shareable link from my google drive
https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B9rvE1lz9fK-aFFFYUNzMm5tOE0/view?usp=sharing
Install that guy
If you don't have a xbox live account, make a free one by going to signup.live.com, make an account, then sign in to xbox.com
The game should launch no problem, you'll sign-in and put in the key, It'll need an update, do said update and restart the game.
Sign in one more time
There all better. It looks like a lot of steps but it shouldn't take more than 5-10 minutes.

On to the review.
Had this game for 360 and played it for hours and hours. Beat the story a dozen times, got all the endings and all that jazz. I haven't tested multiplayer on the pc version yet, but it really made the game for me on xbox. A friend of mine and I did a 12 hour straight run through, doing every side mission and such, and it was awesome.

The graphics are fairly well improved from the xbox version, really it's just added anti-aliasing, but that makes it so much prettier.

If you enjoy creative weaponry, killing zombies, and B horror movie story lines, then this is the game for you. Unlike many sequel type things, In my humble opinion, this series has gotten better each time. So once you're done with this one, you should absolutely buy the third game, as it is even more amazing.

reviewText:
Dead Rising 2 is a game that drops you in the middle of a zombie infested mall, with your ability to concoct the strangest weapon in existence as your only weapon. The greatest asset of this game is the ways in which you can take the environement, and destroy hordes of zombies with it. With some of the most enjoyable weapons in games, memorable and challenging boss battles, some of the best coop gameplay I've seen in years, time management mechanics that add replayability, great controls, some nice visuals for the time of its release, a lovable Capcom style campy story and cheesy dialogue that keeps you anticipating the next one-liner, Dead Rising 2 offers hours and multiple playthroughs of fun.

I'm also glad to say that the PC port is the superior version minus the lack of availability of the Case West DLC, and is actually one of the best PC ports I've played in a while. The PC controls are intuitive, the graphics are a step up from its console iterations, and the patches for the game's major issues on release (saving kicking coop partner and inability for coop partner to save progress are examples) is included.

The game has its problems however, which I think are necessary to point out for the sake of the reader and potential buyer. The first is the overabundance of quick-time-events. I honestly consider QTEs to be a bad mechanic 100% of the time, due to it stripping the gameplay to, press x to watch what happens next" or
date: "press x to not die." Unfortunately this game makes you go through one everytime a zombie gets his hands on you. The button prompt changes everytime
recommended: so you can't just anticipate it and get it over with quickly
hoursPlayed: luckily the prompts are always one of the movement keys or waving the mouse around. The PC port's use of Game for Windows Live is probably the PC version's second greatest flaw. Games for Windows Live is horribly unoptimized
voteText: and is a chore to use in comparison to Steam. Another issue is one I previously mentioned
helpfulPercent: the fact that the Case West DLC has not been ported
votesHelpful: and is not available on PC
votesTotal: so if playing Case West is a must for you
votesFunny: you might want to consider getting this game for PS3 or Xbox 360
commentsCount: although I'd argue it isn't worth the sacrifices made for the console versions. Two very minor complaints are Chuck's slow movement speed
column16: because sometimes I find myself getting impatient with Chuck's inability to go faster than a jog
column17: and how New Game+ doesn't up the difficulty any. I will say however
column18: that New Game+ is fun in the way that you can try and complete all of the missions before their timers run out
column19: due to you being much stronger.\n\nDespite its issues
column20: Dead Rising 2 rounds out to be a wonderful game

reviewText:
It is unfortunate the series has never been able to shed the annoyance of having a time limit. Why must I play a game with time constraints?

It is not necessarily a problem should there be a game mode where this can be turned off. But there's none. I know once you're done with the story the game offers a sort of unlimited game mode for the purpose of just eliminating zombies, still, I would prefer the gameplay Dead Island has. You can go around and look for lootable items and complete side missions and you can also trigger the next main story mission if you want. There are no time constraints here and everything can be done at your pace.

I know there was a deliberate reason for not going ahead with this when Capcom came up with the series. It was decided with a purpose that there should be a time limit so that players cannot feel completeness - I think somewhere in a forum on the internet a guy put it right when he compared this game to the fun park experience of a child: the kid cannot really try out everything but must, instead, make a decision as to what to do and leave the rest for the future. It is all about making a priority list.

So, while the game feels rushed it seems you should set a priority to the list of things you want to do. And those you fail (including a lot of side missions where you need to save people) can later on be dealt with in your next playthrough. So, yes, I really understand what they were trying to pull off, still, I did not like it.

If you are not bothered by time constraints and you are OK with maximising everything throughout several playthroughs then Dead Rising 2 is clearly for you.

As for me: I like taking things at my leisure so this game felt too fast-paced and I was annoyed how many side missions I failed due to not being fast enough. Dead Rising 2 is not a bad game, though! And instead of not recommending" it I wish there was a button of neutrality but since there are only 2 options available I am inclined towards the thumbs down."

reviewText:
I know, I know, yet ANOTHER zombie game. I initially dismissed this game as nothing more than a poor L4D competitor, I was wrong.

DR2 is a completely different game, in almost every way. You have a RPG-styled character with upgrades and perks. You have hundreds of 'weapons' you can use to annoy or wipe out zombies. The storyline isn't too bad, but if you co-op through it with some crazy costumes on the main character, it has some hilarious cutscenes.

Stability wise, the game is not friendly to alt-tab, and the co-op play is also bug ridden with random disconnects. If you can stay together, it's a fun time battling missions, sharing weapons, building awesome combo weapons, driving new vehicles, and of course... killing zombies. Unfortunately, it's only a good experience about every 1 out of 3 or 4 times.

If you're a single-player person, you'll find a lot to do with a good campaign, and some very, very tough bosses. If you're in it for co-op, buckle up for some fun and frustration.

reviewText:
Dead Rising 2 is a game that suffers greatly from being ported to PC. The graphics and technology behind the game is severely dated and it plays and looks like a game much older than it actually is. The limited options and controls that's carried over from the console game doesn't help either.

The storyline is easily forgettable and the voice-acting is mediocre at best. The characters are 99% forgettable and main villain gets quickly pushed into the background by the various psychopaths wearing random costumes you will have to fight along the way.

All of this is forgivable however because of the pure simple mind numbing fun of the core gameplay: Killing zombies with whichever random and illogical object is at hand. It is a simple but hugely entertaining mechanic although one that should only be taken in small doses.

The game's multi-player works great as well although the fact that it uses GFWL will make it real hard to find people to play with.

A good buy at a decent discount.

reviewText: Dead Rising 2 is a serviceable entry-level action game, lacking some of the magic of the first game, but with some novel twists on the formula. Combo weapons, while fun to craft and utilize, make regular weapons like benches and chairs completely worthless. Rather than scrambling to find something to defend yourself with like in the first game, you often find yourself scrambling to find the next janitors closet to duct-tape knives to a boxing glove for the 500th time. The bosses are a step down in terms of humor, though not in challenge; while the average zombie is a bit docile in comparison to their counterparts first game. Fun with friends but they've likely moved on to other games by now. Don't pay more than $10

reviewText:
A ton of people grief over the lack of controller support and the need for a GFWL account. So much so that I put off getting this game for about 6 months even though I wanted it pretty badly. I'm telling you, it's super effing simple to get a GFWL account and it's equally effing simple to get your gampad working. You need to make a hotmail or msn account to use when signing up for gfwl, There is a lot of bad information about what to download to get a gampad working out there. The app most people will direct you to downloaded has been updated to a version that will not work with dead rising 2. When you try to download this file from the official site you find from googling it on your own, you will be told the file is outdated. Click download anyway. Extract to your dead rising 2 folder, open the program and find your gamepad.

So there, the game works fine if you're willing to spend a little time fussing with it. If you have any questions about it not working feel free to message me and Ill try to help you through it.

10/10 Even with a few shortcomings, I never get tired squiring zombies with ketchup and mustard before moving them down with a lightsaber in my underwear.

reviewText:
This game will supposedly coming to steamworks, so a major reason I dont recommend this game is due to the Games For Windows Live fiasco... No idea why most games didnt do the fallout 3 path adn give you a choice to use GFWL from the getgo.

So after far too long figuring out and actually fixing GFWL. You have to uninstall it, reinstall, update and restart your pc 3-ish times, make sure the double security is off on your live accont which may not be what you want so use a throwaway account... and is about to be removed from all games, capcom announced they will shift their games over to steamworks.

They had a sale before doing this though so headaches ahead. Ill keep this short, as for the game itself.

Its okay. The combat is funny the use of everything from a sledgehammers and chainsaws to throwing hotdogs and the tables they were sitting on at enemies is good fun. However when thats the only enjoyable part of the game it gets old (even ducttaping two chansaws to the ends of a kayak paddle is only novel for so long)

The problem is the odd choice of zombies being what you'd expect form a zombie game, slow lumbering and in need of dismemberment and decaptiation to kill them, to the weird human (usually psychotic) bosses you come across trying to cook the other few survivors.

Fun concept but the human bosses dont work by the game rules established, you and zombies and other living people stumble, fall and react to being hit. These bosses are all on pcp and suffering early forms of madcow and run around faster than you can, do not stumble and when they do recover in an instant they hit you for insane amounts of damage where you and 20 12 gauge rounds barely dent their health.

If capcom ever sells this game for a couple bucks and GFWL is gone, itll be totally worth it for the zombie bashing alone. The animations are good (capcom games tend to do this very well) Its not for everyone though, once GFWL is gone itll have a good place in history, aside from the impossible bosses, they are sidequests though so they arent required. its just not for me and likely not for a lot of people.

reviewText:
The first couple of hours I spent with this game I was attempting to get GFWL to function correctly, so the game sort of shot itself in the foot before it was out of the gate.

In general, the game has a lot of great ideas of how to have fun while surviving the zombie apocalypse, but the tone of the game never seems to suit them.  There are so many silly weapons I would love to utilize in a room full of zombies, but who has the time when you've got to find medication for your daughter and save every other nonundead human in the city?  The story's so grim, but the gameplay's so zany; and when the two are mixed, neither one is a positive experience.

What the Dead Rising franchise needs is a sandbox mode:  No time pressure, and no one to save or escort or coddle, and maybe weapons that can endure more than just a handful of whacks-- Nothing but the freedom to explore and bash zombies to your heart's content.  But as it stands, the game is just a chore.

reviewText:
This game requires freaking Games for Windows Live which is alrdeay annoying. The Games for Windows Live registration process is so frustrating if you don't already have an Xbox Live account. It freaking takes forever to get Windows for Games Live account. The thing is useless and disconnects a LOT. The software itself is poorly made. I think everyone can agree to that.

Also this game has the tendency to not freaking work when you download it wrong. When you complete downloading it, the game asks you if you want it to run through steam. People usually say yes because thats the case with most games. BUT for this  game you have to say no. Otherwise you cannot run it through Windows for Game. Then you gotta uninstall, download it AGAIN, then say no on that previous pop up which you said yes to.

The gameplay is ok at best. I found the gameplay just an average zombie kiling game. The highlight of this game is you customize your unique weapon. That gets boring after your first one. If your looking for cool way to customize your weapon, go play Borderlands or something. I haven't even touched this game after few hours of it.

reviewText:
I cannot stress enough that this game even though it looks all great becasue it has finally been taking off Games for Windows Live it is still tremendously broken. I have noticed many complaints and problems on how to conect to friends and join multiplayer games and there is no sufficiently known guide to assist you to be able to stop the game for crashing or not being able to connect to friends and random player on the game.

If you are looking to play this game singleplayer then fair enough, go ahead you will enjoy it. But if you're like me who buys this game for the sheer fun you will get out of it with friends then I have to downvote this game on Steam due to the lack support out there for being able to connect online.

I also have to mention that I got this game when it was on the Steam Summer Sales for Â£5.08 and I find it disgusting that Valve would put the game up for sale at all when it is clearly unstable for some individuals including myself. I hope people reading this can understand my frustration with this and both Capcom and Valve have dissapointed me.

reviewText:
Little did I know if you play this game with a friend, it tests your friendship to the greatest â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing length. Most likely, either your game or your friend's will be broken and that's just the beginning of the greatest experience.

I ran around as an edgy skater kid while my friend was Davy Crockett as we beat up people with boxing gloves with bowie knives attached to them, essentially a wolverine cosplay at best. We have quite the amount of stories to tell, as my friend was blown the â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ out of a map by a nerd on roller skates, we trapped a marine with PTSD into a shipping container as he threw grenades at himself, we beat up two lesbians with our edgy boxing gloves, had to go back to the start of overtime mode because I thought we could save our game after we got a USB drive, and mauled countless zombies with tricycles.

Needless to say, must own and must see.

reviewText:
Dead Rising 2 was the first Dead Rising game that has come to PC and it is a great game lets look at the positives and negatives.
+Tons of zombies.
+Fun gameplay.
+No Framerate Issues in the PC version well none that I could detect.
+Tons to do in the game.
+Combo Weapons lots of them and interesting ways to kill zombies.
+You can play the entire story mode with a friend which doubles the fun.
+Tons of references to the Capcom games,
+Quite challengeing especially the bosses.

reviewText:
It's an interesting premise, but it's very poorly executed.

The controls are very unresponsive, every action you take feels like you're wading through sludge. The save system is the 90s console savepoint that everyone hates, and there is no autosave so you will often lose 30 mins plus from random nonsense, often related to problems with the controls.

There is a level up system, but it's obviously an afterthought as it's disappointingly basic. The crafting system is also very weak.

If you can get hold of a copy of the first game I'd recommend playing that instead.

reviewText:
Probably put over 100 hours into the console version but this version beats it in so many ways! First off, mods! I love modding games, but there are amazing modders out there who have figured out how to make weapon mods (a shotgun that shoots saw blades, etc.) and other great ones like 10x the ammount of zeds in game (which ended up being too much for me because I couldn't get anywhere with out fighting through hundreds of zed.)

The story continues on several years after the first DR game and focuses on a new protagonist, Chuck Green, former motocross racer, who is just trying to make enough money to get his daughter the medicine that she needs every day. Chaos ensues and the story continues and Chuck meets surivors and tries to get them back to a safehouse to await an army evacuation. There is a lot of weapon combinations to change things up in the game as well as the usual Capcom soliciting it's own games within this game (Mega Man anyone?) It's tons of gore with quite a lot of stupid funny" moments sprinkled in. You like survivng the zombie apocalypse? Buy this game!

All in all I've loved Dead Rising from the beginning
date: and I can't wait for September for DR3 to come to PC!"

reviewText: Great game, it's really fun to build custom weapons. The Vegas setting is cool, the graphics are beautiful, and the gameplay can be fun. Can, that's right. I'm one of those persons that doesn't like it when you have to beat the clock. It puts pressure on me when all I want to do is kill zombies and explore. You know, in a relaxing way. You won't be exploring much, I can tell you that. Another thing I don't like are the random bosses. Don't get me wrong, I love bossfights, but I think the game should save first so you don't lose all your progress up to that point. These bosses can be very tough and frustrating and it makes me want to avoid them instead of fight them. It may seem I'm not really positive about this game, but I really, really do like it and I suggest you give it a shot if you're into zombie games and third person survival horror games.\n\n[Rating: 80/100]

reviewText:
If you're wondering why i've not got any gaming hours against this game it's because I cannot play this game, It's got so many problems I've yet to make it past 6mins!

I've rented Dead Rising 2 on Xbox 360 before and thoroughly enjoyed what I played. My reason to not recommend this game on PC/Steam is not because I dislike the game, I've actually been wanting to own this for years but I've been waiting until it became cheap enough on any platform to buy two copies so I can play with my partner. Well It seemed like a good deal on Steam...

BUT BOY WAS I WRONG!

This game is plagued with installation, client update and registration issues. Honestly just Google Dead Rising won't start in Steam"
date: I wish I had done this prior to purchasing TWO copies. The game doesn't launch straight off the bat
recommended: It has issues launching Microsoft Games For Windows Live (GFWL) - Which is understandable considering no manual or company actually informs you that this needs to be installed until you've purchased the game and are frantically searching the web for answers. The problems don't end there
hoursPlayed: once GFWL is installed it requires you to log in about 3-4 times over and over as it has to do multiple updates
voteText: I experienced different outcomes for each of the two copies I installed. One updated fine and then threw constant errors trying to connect to XB Live. The other computer failed to install the second update then suggested I check the error logs buried deep in my User/Appdata folder. The troubleshooting and manual fixes just keep coming beyond this point. After finally logging into GFWL I managed to start a game only to have it Crash on me in the first cutscene. This is as far as I've got
helpfulPercent:
I'm frustrated having paid $20 for each copy but after the many hours I've spent troubleshooting this game before even playing it I'd be annoyed even paying $5 for such an experience. In fact I'd put money on the fact that I would probably have a smoother ride getting a pirated game to work.

There is a fundimental problem plaguing PC gaming these days and if it weren't for hardcore PC gaming fans I doubt anyone would stick around and put up with this problem to support PC gaming.

All thanks to Pirating there now are OODLES too many third parties involved in the licensing and registration of games now. Long gone are the days where you could just buy a game on DVD
votesHelpful: insert the disc
votesTotal: type a CD Key and 15mins later DONE! The game is ready to play
votesFunny: with maybe the exception of a minor patch.\n\nNow days EVERY godamn company involved with the games development or distribution has to clip the ticket and request you sign up to their own Game Client Service just so they can mine your personal information and gaming habits. Now I know this is somewhat designed to stop pirating but at what cost? This makes buying a legitimate game such a slow and painful process when you have to download multiple game clients
commentsCount: register multiple accounts and download multiple updates. Keep this up and people WILL pirate more! What makes the whole process even more painful and flawed is that none of these Third Party services seem to actually communicate or co-operate with one another
column16: so when one link in the chain fails they all point fingers and the poor man in the middle (US GAMERS) seeks advice or support we get shunted in the opposite direction everytime... Think about asking for a refund? Your dreaming! IT'S A JOKE!\n\nThis is not an isolated issue either
column17: it's affecting hundreds of games these days. I'm a hardcore PC Gamer
column18: I've loved this platform for years but I'm just about OVER IT!"

reviewText:
As much i as love this game, as much as loved this on console, this game is a terrible port.
i can play up until the first 2 hours and the second you leave for the hotel, the game crashes. i can only play the game for two hours before it f**ks up. i didn't pay 20$ to have my game crash every time i try to play the game.
But maybe i dont need to do the main story, maybe i could just â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ around in the open world bit, Right? NO! beacause everytime i exit the game, i return to find thet every one of my save files are corrupted. and this hasn't been once or twice, no, its happened to me FIVE TIMES!
not to mention that i had to re-install the game twice in order to boot it up. i had to install GFWL :(, and make an entirely new email account in order to boot this game, it took me two hours to boot the game, and what for? the game crashes constantly and corrups when you stop playing.
Honestly, i love this game, and i love the franchise, but if you want to play this, i highly recommend that you buy it for console, solely to avoid the crashes and the constant corruption.

reviewText:
Dead Rising 2 is an interesting title. Granted that some people will find the time element annoying, I personally find it well done and think it works.
DR2 is all about killing zombies, and saving your daughter, although it is much, MUCH more free than any other game. If you wanted to, you could simply hide in a broom closet the whole game, you wouldnt get a very good ending, you wouldnt have much fun, but you can do it. Likewise, if you want to do every quest, you can go for it, although that is possibly the most stressful thing you can do.
Like I stated previously, DR2 is more free than any other game, you can use whatever you want as a weapon, and you can combine things together. For instance, say you want a spiked bat, take a baseball bat and nails and put em on the workbench. Want a light sabe- sorry - laser sword? Take a flashlight and put some gems on it.
sadly this game in all its humorous glory doesnt go without its fair share of glitches.
granted it is rare to run into them but there have been several reports of textures not appearing, and on occasion not being able to do a mission
the guide arrow is very misleading
but these flaws are few and far between
this game is a zombie killing RPG that doesn't take itself too seriously, and although it is a short review I give it my highest recommendation...
9/10
...
thats what i would say



BUT IN ALL REALITY: I cannot recommend this game as of now. Granted it is very fun, open and enjoyable, as it turns out GFWL is shutting down next year. meaning you can no longer play TIR, and you can no longer activate it or even save. that is the most disappointing part. this is a lot of wasted potential. do not buy at all costs get it for xbox

reviewText:
Dead Rising 2 is an interesting title. Granted that some people will find the time element annoying, I personally find it well done and think it works.
DR2 is all about killing zombies, and saving your daughter, although it is much, MUCH more free than any other game. If you wanted to, you could simply hide in a broom closet the whole game, you wouldnt get a very good ending, you wouldnt have much fun, but you can do it. Likewise, if you want to do every quest, you can go for it, although that is possibly the most stressful thing you can do.
Like I stated previously, DR2 is more free than any other game, you can use whatever you want as a weapon, and you can combine things together. For instance, say you want a spiked bat, take a baseball bat and nails and put em on the workbench. Want a light sabe- sorry - laser sword? Take a flashlight and put some gems on it.
sadly this game in all its humorous glory doesnt go without its fair share of glitches.
granted it is rare to run into them but there have been several reports of textures not appearing, and on occasion not being able to do a mission
the guide arrow is very misleading
but these flaws are few and far between
this game is a zombie killing RPG that doesn't take itself too seriously, and although it is a short review I give it my highest recommendation...
9/10
...
thats what i would say



BUT IN ALL REALITY: I cannot recommend this game as of now. Granted it is very fun, open and enjoyable, as it turns out GFWL is shutting down next year. meaning you can no longer play TIR, and you can no longer activate it or even save. that is the most disappointing part. this is a lot of wasted potential. do not buy at all costs get it for xbox

reviewText:
Dead Rising 2. Well, this was a ride.

Let me just say it out of the bat.  It's a great game, it's fun, the characters are interesting, the gameplay is solid. It's a riot all the way. It's pretty short storywise, however the point of the game is replaying the campaign several times with better items, higher levels and trying to get all the content in the time you have alloted.

This game would be easily a 9/10 for me if not for 3 things:

1. It took me some time to get it to work. Several tweaks, swapping data files, etc. to get it running. Be sure to check the forums before starting the game

2. GFWL. I always get a bit concerned when a game has this service for online anything. It isn't as bad in this game, since you only need to confirm once when you start the game, but still.

3. Controller. This game doesn't recognize any controller besides the 360 controller. so, if you have a dualshock or any other type, it won't read it.

If you can put up with those things up there, you'll get to enjoy a pretty enjoyable game.

Update: Problems 1 and 2 are gone. After the steamworks update, the game doesn't require data and tweaks to run anymore and Steamworks is smooth as silk compared to GFWL old bloated overlay.

Complete recommendation, get this or Off the Record when you get the chance.

reviewText:
8/10 This is exactly how zombie games should be. It's crazy and ridiculous, but not in a stupid way. The story is also interesting. It's a free-roam game that starts over with a New Game+  after a few days or when you choose to. So you can be responsible and do all the scheduled story missions, or mess around collecting money, kills, and XP until the game starts over. (don't worry you keep all your money, XP, and unlockables) The time limit isn't that bad and barely interupts exploration but you sometimes need to hurry for story missions. Co op is extremely fun! The only problems are unexpected or frustrating boss fights you need to prepare for and there isn't much incentive to continue after maxing your level and finishing the story.

+Awesome combat
+Feels great to get money and levelup
+You can go anywhere and pick up almost anything
+Lots of weapon combinations
-Frustrating bosses
-Somewhat low level cap.

â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥it â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ capcom gives us actual controller support. yeah the controls for the keyboard are a little â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥, you can use a controller but you have to download something I forgot what its called and I don't give a â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥. reviewText:
Dead Rising 2 is so lame, I doubt I'll ever go past 3 hours.

The problem isn't the performance, the port is flawless. It offers you many options which is great fo both the high-end gamer as well as well as the gamers who are not so lucky.  The controls are decent. The art style is, well it's Capcom.. need I say more? Capcom = the king of average in the graphics department. The problem is that the game lacks personality. It hasn't a heart, nor a soul. In that way, the zombie theme is quite fitting.

Hmmm... maybe I just don't dig Capcom's sense of humor but this is probably the most boring zombie game out there, unless you find dressing up a guy in various women's clothing as entertaining. I rarely recommend other games over the game I'm reviewing in the actual review but I recommend Dying Light over this...

http://store.steampowered.com/app/239140

If you're still interested in Dead Rising 2, I would strongly suggest looking the game up on YouTube to give you an idea of what it has to offer. It's more comedic than anything. It's like Saints Row but if you took all the good gameplay aesthetics and filled the game with zombies who have horrible ai. I'm quite disappointed because Dead Rising 3 on Xbox One/PC is so much fun. Can this one even be in the same family? Unoriginal, uninspired, plain rubbish compared to the 1st and 3rd in the series.

Come on Capcom, this is the second game by you guys that I cannot recommend sadly.

Review based on most current build, bought on a sale price.

reviewText:
Don't get me wrong with my negative review, the game is awesome and ways to kill zombies are epic, I'm giving negative because guys from Capcom are joking with THAT MUCH bugged multiplayer (TiR). They released this game on steam and still didn't fix something, what is really easy to fix!!

There is story, also story that is limited by time, what is to be honest pretty annoying, there are so many great ways to kill zombies, but you can't really enjoy it as you are limited with time. I really enjoyed playing single player, making combos, finding hidden gems in Fortunate city everything while killing many many zombies. Zombies are everywhere just like it should be, that's the point of zombie games :)

Dead multiplayer is bugged, so I totally not recommend it for achievement hunters!
- Progress in winning TiR for host doesn't count
- Game crashes for every participant in the end of Slycycles competition,
- When it crashes it doesn't save progress for everyone (there's steam guide how to make it save),
- Problems in finding hosted lobby (you are just getting in the unending cycle of creating own lobby instead of join friend).

Ways that I was thinking about to fix this game: for example adding bots to TiR, making slycycles not crash, removing TiR achievements. Sorry I have always thought Capcom is too serious developer, so letting it be bugged like this is something unexpected.

I will be happy to make this review positive once they fix it.
Btw I'm on 17th place in TiR global rankings lol :D

Dead Rising 2 mempunyai cerita dan alur yang sangat bagus. Bercerita tentang seorang bapak yang sangat menyayangi anaknya, yang rela berkerumun melawan ratusan bahkan ribuan bahkan puluh ribuan zombie. Demi mendapatkan zombrex obat penawar bagi anaknya yang telah terinfeksi.

Berbekal palu, pipa, bahkan ember sebagai senjata, pemain harus menyelesaikan misi-misi penyelamatan diantara banyak gedung yang terlihat dalam peta. Adapun misi utama adalah untuk menyelidiki asal mula bagaimana infeksi zombie ini bermula.

Grafis lumayan bagus, ada unsur konyol.

Nilai
8/10

reviewText:
I will first start off with explaining the cons.

cons-
1. no auto saves/ not enough bathrooms to save in

The problem with this game is that it is huge, this makes me wonder why there is no auto save feature in this game, or at least why there aren't more bathrooms to save in. Spoiler altert... A man with a pice of glass who is way overpowered attempts to shank you in one of the bathrooms.

2. Although this isn't as big as a problem as number 1, there is almost no way to find zombrex in this game without looking it up. I get that its a zombie appocalipse and you are trying to save your daughter who is infected, but why have this feature when it is almost impossible to find zombrex. The zombrex prediciment just takes away from the whole point of the game, which is killing zombies.

3. you can't run, as if the developers just want to add time to the game.

Pros-

1. Customization. Customization in this game is amazing. I love combining weapons and wearing different clothing, its a truely unique aspect of this game.

2. Zombie killing is overall very enjoyable. Co-op with friends is even better.

Overall, I give this game a 6.5/10. It's a fun game, but there are a lot of very annoying things that could have easily been fixed.

The game would not open on its own after downloading. So i had to research online to find out that you are required to download windows live game service in order to even boot the game.

Once the game was booted I had to install a bunch of updates through the windows live service. After that I had to create a new windows ID so i could log in or else the game was telling me it would not save my game.

Now I've come to learn that the game WILL NOT accept anything controller but the wired Xbox controller (emulation and various other do it yourself fixes not withstanding)

I was did not like the first game because weird â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥t it put me through on the 360.  I only decided to take a chance on this because it was on sale and it looked like a huge gameplay improvement. but after this whole ordeal im pledging that this is that last time i ever deal with capcoms crap. I shouldt have to book a day off work just to get the game working to atone for the sin of having purchised it through steam.

reviewText:
I DID enjoy this game, had microsoft not decided to butt right into the middle of PC gaming. Quite frankly they should have stayed where they were with xbox. GFWL (games for windows live) is essentially another copy of steam, one however that dosent work.

Heres why:
-no customer support (i will go into detail later)
-awful layout
-dosent work (again, explained later in the recommendation)

The game itself is very good as it provides a huge amount of fun when it does happen to work. my problem (if you cant tell by now) is with the enourmous cockup that capcom have provided with GFWL.

After getting dead rising working on my laptop i had a good couple of hours playing on it, however...... my laptop broke a few days later. After getting my new PC, which was far better than the laptop, i decided to download dead rising for a bit of fun. Heres where the problems start - after launching it says to please log in using my games for windows live account, i enter my details and it then asks for the product key (at this point im getting confused as ive just logged in on the account that i already activated the product on) after entering my product key it says that its already been activated on another account. at this point im starting to get angry as ive just logged in, like i said, on the account that i already activated it on. after this first issue it then says that i seem to have no internet..... after this next incredably annoying problem (as i plainly do have internet at this point) it gives me an error code. finaly i think i may be able to get somewhere as to my knowledge i have a reason for why i cant log in and play the game i gave them Â£15 to buy. after managing to navigate their awfull website through the aid of a friend (yes, it really is that bad) i get to the customer support. Now its telling me that in order to try and solve my problems i have to talk to a representative who dosent actually work for microsoft and therefor cant help me with the issues ive had so far. He suggests to try entering my error code into their database of 'all' error codes. I put this in quotations of course because according to the database of 'all things errors' my problem turns out to not exist. By now ive spent around 3 hours just trying to get onto the game ive payed my hard earned money to get, and cant because of the terrible organisation  at microsofts end.

My verdict:
Pros:
-good fun game with many enjoyable gameplay features

Cons:
-that really is the only good point about this purchase that i can think of
-the entire paragraph that i wrote :/

Overall:
DO NOT BUY THIS GAME - unless you know exactly what you are doing when it comes to dealing with errors from microsoft.

Unlike other zombie-themed games, in this game, you are NOT gonna go on a full zombie-massacre spree. Instead, you have to RUN and AVOID zombies! Which kinda sucks.

The plot and gameplay is pretty boring if you're playing Single Player. Although it is considered as Open World" game

reviewText:
I've owned this game for almost two years now, and I have only been able to play it for 5 hours.  This game says it supports an xbox 360 controller and just had a regular gamepad, i thought I found a workaround, but I was wrong.  I finally caved and bought 360 controller specifically so I can play this game today.  After two years of owning it.  Windows live wants to update.  The update stalls... every time.  So I close live and I try to play anyways.  Guess what?  The option for a controller is greyed out and disabled.  However, even if it had, it wouldn't be able to save because I'm not signed in to games for windows live...

TL;DR

If you like to kill zombies with a controller, and being able to save your progress, don't buy this game.

reviewText: Dead Rising 2 does hordes of enemies better than any other game I've played. It's definitely an experience to leave a building and see hundreds of zombies milling about, all moving independently and all interactable. Most games only manage this number of enemies in cutscenes, not in actual gameplay. There's plenty of room to explore and experiment, and a ton of goofy weapons and skills. I'm really disappointed that there isn't a sandbox mode, but you'll make discoveries as you play through the game. A little too much time pressure, but definitely a lot of fun.\n\nFull review here: http://postlaunch.blogspot.ca/2013/11/dead-rising-2.html

reviewText:
Fun game but frustrating UI. The lack of custom waypointing makes rescuing survivors a headache. I just dragged two survivors into a boss fight and now have to restart from a previous savepoint. Speaking of which, the save system is a pain in the â™¥â™¥â™¥ too.
Furthermore, the grab distance to close doors and grab items is really short.

It's is a very addicting game. The zombie population is huge even when compared to Left 4 Dead as they fill up the horizon for miles. They are mostly avoidable but you will end up brawling quit a bit espeically at doors where they tend to pile up. Survivors do help, move efficently and can be given weapons to dispatch zombies. There are quite a number of zany ways to deal with them. Broadsword and Baseball Bat Mace seem the most effective so far.

So yeah.. fun game if you are willing to put up with some annoying issues.

reviewText: There's something to be said about the style that Keiji Inafune brings to a project.  Be it Megaman or Res Evil 4, he just knows how to make a good thing better.  Dead Rising 2 may be a his magnum opus when it comes to that.  Epic jumping high kicks, sledgehammers taped to fire axes, giant bull horns, it's a lot of fun.  Even with a relatively weak weapon like the tomahawk can you get endless amounts of fun from chopping zombies.  Food (health) is everywhere so you're never really caught short, which applies to weapons as well.  The combination system is put in very well and there's an unnerving sense hanging ofver the whole game of YOUR DAUGHTER IS GOING TO DIE GET HER SOME MEDICINE YOU MONSTER while I â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ around Fortune City hitting zombies to the tune of Peter Gabriel's 'Sledgehammer'.

reviewText:
While I really like DR2 it reminds me that I really dislike games that have time limits.

But in DR2 you can sort of completely ignore any or all of the timers and have your fun slashing and exploding hundreds of thousands of zombies.

The hack and slash gameplay is still weirdly stiff, like the oringinal, but the graphics are fasntastic, and the story is at least somewhat interesting this time around with great main characters.

It's so close to being a fantastic game, it just tries way too hard (for me) to be challenging or weird (like the stiff controls and time limites) that it takes a bit away from the fun.

reviewText:
This game is my only favourite zombie killing game so far. There is a lot of things to do on a large entartaintment site. Time limited main and side tasks, gaining combo cards and making different weapons, changing your appearence and so on. Decent story, good gameplay.

However, when i finished the game, i didn't want to play so much. Even the game doesn't touch your character level and learned combo cards, you have to restart the story if you want to play the game again. Of course, you can do other side tasks you didn't do before but... i think that's not so fun. But that's not the downside of the game.

I strongly recommend it, especially if you don't like zombie games and stories. Give it a try.

reviewText:
Combining items to make new and amusing weapons is a great idea, and generally it plays well, but the game has a very annoying flaw that ruined the experience for me.

The main flaw is that you are constantly on a timer, and mostly for no good reason. It means you can't just explore, create new weapons and have fun, because if the arbitrary timer runs out it's the end of the game and you have to reload, often from quite a long way back. For this reason, I would recommend Dead Island in preference to this game.

reviewText:
Personal Rating: 4 of 10

Before you begin judging this review do take time to read why I gave it a 4. This is a pretty decent game with tonnes of potential. To top it all, it comes with a great plot which is the only thing to keeps me playing.

As you can already see, Dead Rising 2 is a zombie massacre game with seemingly illogical/nonsensical gameplay with a dash of humour. You can do cosplay, dress-up, mix and match almost anything you can find in the game to create new weapons and discover new ways to slaughter the zombies. But with all this, the plot actually comes up as rather serious and touching. Personally, I think the ridiculous dress-up (unless you buy the DLC) that comes with no purpose, spoils the mood. Imagine you are comforting your daughter dressed in a womens under garment.

The gameplay, as you can already see is exactly what and as it is. Each mission, you are to butcher your way out with whatever weapon you can find laying around. The weapons degrade rather quickly so you will need to get use to what is available to you. Combining weapons can be a chore as your inventory is extremely limited and finding the right weapons to combine requires you to do a little hunting while holding on to them. Not to mention you will need to stock up on food and bonus pamphlet (seems like it) that takes up even more inventory slot. Larger weapons/props does not allow you to store them so you will need to hold on to it as your primary weapon until you find a maintenance room.

Side missions will require you to fetch items, escort survivors, fight mini bosses and etc. Survivors are annoying as they can come up with ridiculous requests and they also die rather easily. Handing them weapons is a great strategy but hanging to a good weapon for them will again take up your slot. I have no issue with the AI as the path finding and combat intelligent is alright. However, boss fights, again is another chore. You simply need to find the right timed action to perform and repeat until they dies.

This game solely focuses on killing zombies to the extend that they actually respawn right in front of you if you manage to clear them off in a large scale in an open area. Just like that, poof! and there appear right there. You cannot store weapons in your base when there are plenty of boxes/cupboard lying around. It is also really sad that you cannot expand or relocate your base when you can actually clear out the mall bit by bit.

After a while, you will get bored and simply pushes off and avoid the zombies by travelling within the shop in the mall. I have no idea why the zombies will not spawn in the store. Maybe its because random looters will spawn in them time to time; which again makes no sense as they are yelling and breaking stuff but the zombies simply ignores them.

Maybe on co-op it will give you more dynamics and options. I only manage to play the campaign and it really is annoying and frustrating rather then fun.

reviewText:
Timed Escort Mission: The Game.
Literally.
If we're gonna judge it on the obnoxiousness of its timed escort missions though, then it just barely comes short of MGS2. The timed escort missions in this game aren't underwater, but damn if they aren't trying. What with how often you get put into long grabbing animations by zombies that you have to QTE your way out of.
The graphics look like â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ for the most part, with textures on zombies that are about 256x256, no joke, and textures on humans that look to be about 1024x1024 at the greatest, but the game remains very well optimized. I can manage 60+ FPS even when there are hundreds of zombies on screen, so that makes up for the decreptitude of the graphics.
The gameplay of Dead Rising 2 is very advanced. The combat comes close to legendary titles like Devil May Cry 4 in depth, with profound mechanics like vomit cancelling and the part where you hit the lumbering undead with a large blunt weapon repetedly.
Overall, this is a very good port. Extremely enjoyable co-op. 7 out of 10 Gamecubes.
Not quite giga-cube level, but still a veritable source of giggles for you and an amigo possibly playing with you.
Also I never want to see a shopping mall again.

Basically, this is an open world 3rd-person zombie apoalypse game completely ruined by a horrible save system.

reviewText:
On it's own merits, as someone who is new to the Dead Rising franchise, I found this game to be unbearably dull.

The game generally goes like this:

Start Game -> Loading Screen -> Cutscene -> Loading Screen -> Cutscene -> Loading Screen -> Walk across corridor -> Loading Screen -> Cutscene triggered -> Loading screen -> Walk for a small amount -> Loading Screen...

You get the point. It is *extremely* cutscene heavy. Furthermore, it is using Games for Windows Live, a service that will be shut down on July 1, 2014. Even if the game utilised Steam's mechanics, this game is still so painfully slow.

I managed to get into the mall to find loads of zombies and some objects. I pick up the object and attack the zombies, which with the sluggish controls, doesn't help the situation either. And then I find my items deteriorate after 10(?) hits.

If this sounds like your game, then go for it - I'd only give caution about Games for Windows Live. If this game seems tedious, that's because it is, and Steam offers far better zombie games from AAA developers as well as indie developers. No need to fork our your hard earned cash for this slow drivel.

reviewText: I tried playing this a couple years back and gave up, and I finally got around to picking it up only to give up again. Smashing the zombies is pretty fun, but I was overwhelmed by the time-limited missions that meant I couldn't run around and play for myself. That alone I could cope with, but the limited save slots and lack of an autosave feature or free-saving can significantly backtrack your play, despite the numerous save points nearby.\n\nAll in all, it feels like a game that could have been a lot more fun if you were able to explore and pursue the story and sidequests more freely on your own time, rather than feeling like you're playing to somebody else's schedule.

reviewText:
I feel like this game had two lead developers, we'll call them Tom and Lumpy. Now Tom is a reasonable guy, good head on his shoulders, and has a knack for coming up with good ideas. Lumpy was placed there because he was someone's cousin and someone owed someone else a favor. Lumpy is not a good designer. Lumpy's only talent is to uncerimoniously shart on any new idea presented such that it immediately becomes terrible.

But because he's someone's cousin and someone owed someone else a favor, Lumpy gets veto power over Tom.

So the two sit down at the first development meeting and I imagine the conversation going thusly:

Tom: I think a more open world-style game that allows the player to explore and roam at will through a large area would work best. We can make it a casino, that way there's plenty to do and look at.

Lumpy: Perfect! We can break everything up into chunks that take forever to get through unless you run and miss most everything interesting!

Tom: Erm...ok, so as far as story, let's have the plot revolve around the main character's daughter. They've developed a cure but she has to keep taking it.

Lumpy: Great! We can attach it to a timed mechanic that means you have to sprint through the complex and sprawling levels to get back to her to give her medicine or else she dies and the game instantly ends.

Tom: Ummm...I guess. I was also thinking we could do the custom weapons thing again. See what kind of crazy things players will come up with.

Lumpy: I love it! Then we'll make these weapons super fragile so they break near immediately and the components are hard to get so you don't get to use them hardly ever and the rest of the time you just have to wail on zombies with whatever is handy!

Tom: *sigh* Ok, ok, ok. The main character is a reporter, so let's include a kind of photography system. Adds a new dimmension to game play and opens up a lot of avenues for sharable content and humor.

Lumpy: Brilliant! We can force that to be a core part of gameplay and jerk the player out of the action and tension with unnecessarily long animations and grading screens!

Tom (who by now is close to tears): I...I guess we can do that...but we need something to add some tension to the game. The daughter thing is good but some overarching tension in terms of the surroundings would be great.

Lumpy: I know! Let's have the whole game run on a timer so that you have to race through and miss most of the cool stuff before the time runs out or you automatically die! And it'll mean people have to replay the game over and over again!

Tom: ...I hate you so much right now.



That's about the formula for the game; take one good idea and smash it to death with bad ones until you find yourself sobbing at your desk asking the game gods why and wishing dearly to be able to get this game out of your library.

reviewText:
First Dead Rising was like a Metal Gear Solid of the zombie games.
Serious and original investigation story (That's right, zombie game over here.), Likable characters, Fresh experience to both zombie action and survival games, Good soundtrack, Believable psychopaths, Interesting photo mechanics. Along with everything above, DR never took itself too serious, that's why it was so charismatic.
None of that in Dead Rising 2. And i feel great shame that PC gamers had to ruin their experience with this piece of â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥, instead of playing actual masterpiece like first DR.
DR2 is like a degenerate brother of the first one, cliched and rushed story and sudden change of style, turning franchise into some â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing comedy up to the third game. ruining survival feel to it and completely turning it into an action game. Few annoying gameplay choices that at first ruined this game for me. Most annoying of them all is zombrex hunt for your daughter, it makes game very limited for exploration. which is unforgivable for open-world sandbox games like DR. As i remember, first DR had possible but hardcore missions and newbie traps, it required you to get used to it, i didn't mind failing and leveling up a little more to complete the story line, it gave you enough time for that and it felt fair. In DR2 you are punished for not knowing locations of zombrex along with other factors, that limit your free-playtime, FORCING you into multiply re-starts if you are playing for fun. New main character is pretty likable because he represents the player in this new insane and random" style
date: making him the only sane sober-thinking person in the game

reviewText:
I had never played Dead Rising 1 as it was not on PC. I was very into L4D2 logging over 200 hours into it. I had expected Dead Rising 2 to be in the vain of L4D but in third person and whole lot more zombies. Instead I got an open world zombie game with slow pacing, long grind, clunky combat and unbalanced boss fights.

Pros:
Runs well on a AMD Phenom II X4 940, 2GB DDR2 and GTX 670. Sometimes under 60fps.

Cons:
-Huge grind. As described below about boss fights, you need to level up in order for boss fights to be fair. I am at level 20 and boss fights are still not balanced at all. Avoiding boss fights can be futile at times as described below.

-No running. You walk faster by levelling up. Levelling up auto assigns attributes (attack, speed, life etc..) so their is no customization. I am currently at level 20 and still walk very slow.

-Time based gameplay, all missions are based on a certain time, the absence of running really adds frustration to this as you cannot get to some missions in time, especially story missions that forces you to load from a user savepoint which could be 30 mins back.

-Save points are limited to restrooms"

reviewText: A friend and I go this game just looking to â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ about a bit and kill zombies in fun and entertaining ways, and there are tons of hilarious, inventive ways to do that. But the game doesn't want to let you mess around and jave fun. All of the missions are on time limits, which means you'd better get going or else you'll fail and have to reload a save from half an hour ago, 'cause there are no save stations anywhere. Comnime that with the fact that you can only take 4 hits until you level up, and   even then, you only gain one more hit per level, it's hard to just go around wreaking havoc, and it just seems easier to walk around the zombies. Except that the character doesn't control very well and there is a severe lack of a sprint button. The game that I am describing may be what you want, but it isn't what I thought it was going to be.

reviewText:
Final Verdict: D+

As a zombie fan, you really REALLY want to like Dead Rising 2. But it falls short of almost everything it offers and it's attempt at being less shallow with the time constraint actually makes the game even worse. If you had the ability to take your time and just kill and explore at your pace the game would have gotten at least a C.

There is no support for a game controller unless you spend some time getting a control emulator (which is ridiculous in this day and age, especially for a game that's basically a console game). This alone may make you hate the game before you even get to play it.

This game means well, but it doesn't do almost anything for the zombie genre. The best part of the game is how many zombies are visible on the screen at one time. But if you think about it, that's pretty sad.
