reviewText:
It's an improvement over DR1, that's for sure... The survivor A.I. is much better scripted, the layout of the map isn't nearly as obnoxious as it was in the original either... Also, the timer is a lot more mangable and if you follow a survivor rescuing guide you'll realize how much Capcom actually spoon feeds us the survivors this time around... In DR1 it was a disaster to have to guide back more than a couple people, in DR2, it's embraced... the larger the group, the more survivability it has.

I found Chuck to be a lot more stoic and bad â™¥â™¥â™¥ than Frank West and I assume that's what they were going for but playing this after playing DR2: OTR, you realize how much of a blank slate Chuck really is... almost downright boring to watch... but before that little mistake happened, he was just a total bad â™¥â™¥â™¥.

My only gripe is that there's little to no reason to head in to the underground tunnel section of the game and I remember that being one of the most terrifying things about DR1... is that you were essentially forced down there for a lot of reasons... you briefly skim part of it this time around. Also there's a plethora of combo cards in this game and unfortunately 95% of them are novelty gag's or downright worthless. The easiest and earliest combo weapons you can make are among the best in the game, which leaves you little to nothing to look forward to.

The game is much more fair than DR1 which is a great and bad thing all at once. The problem with making things fair in a survival horror game is that it takes away a lot of the fear you'd normally have playing it... Although in this game's defense, you can't really begin to play it seriously until you hit level 50... Trying to accomplish anything profound before level 40 and you're basically zombie fodder. So it's a bit of a grind out...
voteText: 3 of 9 people (33%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
So, things are better now that Steam has worked with the publisher to move the saves over to Steamworks.  Kudos to Steam for helping make that change.  I'm absolutely certain that this will return some good will for people who felt ripped off that they'd paid for an unplayable game (BTW...doing the same for other GFWL titles, would be great).  I know that it made me feel a lot better about Steam's response to the problem, especially as a very long-time Steam member.

As for the game itself, I'm still pretty torn and can't wholly recommend it on PC.  It's a fairly clunky port from consoles, and honestly it probably plays better on those (which pains those of us who are PC gamers).  The save system is still very console-focused and pretty annoying, as a lot of checkpoints are set in an area where there is a high potential of death, and then you're stuck replaying quite a bit just to take another run at the same thing.

The reality is that other zombie titles play much better on PC...Left For Dead 1/2, Dead Island, etc.  If you've blasted through all of those and simply need another zombie killing game on your PC and this is on sale (like it currently is), then it's perhaps still worth it.  Otherwise, move on to stronger titles or at least wait until this one is on sale.

I the meantime, I reluctantly can't give the game a recommendation, even though it's decent.  I'd probably give it a thumbs-up on a console.

reviewText:
This game has been left to die. However, I will not leave you to die.

If you follow these steps, and are focused and determined, the game should work for you, for a while.

How to fix Games for Windows Live on Windows 8 Pro x64
Ironic Fact: GFWL doesnâ€™t really work with Windows 8 Pro x64.

Good Fact: itâ€™s not that difficult to fix.

If GFWL isnâ€™t working for you (best way to check is play a GFWL game and see if you can bring up the home menu. If not, itâ€™s broken) hereâ€™s what to do.

NOTE: YOU MUST MUST MUST DO THESE STEPS EXACTLY. DONâ€™T SKIP ON REBOOTING OR ANYTHING. ALSO MAKE SURE TO DOWNLOAD THE FILE Iâ€™VE LINKED TO, AND NOT ANY OTHER VERSION OF GFWL.

1\ uninstall both â€œMicrosoft Games for Windows - LIVE Redistributableâ€ AND â€œMicrosoft Games for Windows Marketplaceâ€

2\ reboot

3\ download the GFWL installer from http://www.xbox.com/en-US/LIVE/PC/DownloadClient

4\ IMPORTANT: Right click the above installer, go to properties and change its compatibility to â€œWindows 7â€. Save and exit.

5\ IMPORTANT: Right click the installer, and choose â€œRun as administratorâ€

6\ After itâ€™s installed, run the GFWL game again. It should now work fine and redownload your profile.

Steps 4 and 5 are really, REALLY, REALLY important.

reviewText:
One of the best zombie killin action games out there. It keeps you on your toes with the time race and gives you all the fun you can get from the zombie apocalypse: hot chicks are plenty, sick weapons there are even more, ridiculous sidequests like save nerds playing board games or get the drunk stripper out of harm's way. So good luck. And have fun after all ;)

reviewText:
Disclaimer - I do not own Dead Rising 2, I have played the game via Steam family share.
Dead Rising 2 is an open world survival horror beat 'em up game which was released in mid 2010 on both console and PC. You play as Chuck Green, who is a motocross rider, as you try to survive a zombie outbreak. The game is set in a shopping and casino complex which is filled with zombies. You encounter up human survivors throughout the game, as well as finding and crafting weapons.

Game play wise; Dead Rising 2 is a very typical hack and slash style. You find weapons around the levels such as crowbars, sledge hammers, pistols, right the way up to silly items such as garden rakes and party hats.  As you progress through the story you get more experience  points from completing missions and saving survivors. The game is also heavily based around time constraints too; you have to do missions at certain times; if you miss the time you either loose the game or the mission is gone and you can never finish it. This to me made me have to make a lot of sacrifices to what content I actually got to see; I personally didn't see a huge need to have the time constraints in place as you just end up missing out on content that the developers have worked hard to make.

That being said; all of the missions and side quests are virtually all the same. Side missions consist of finding the survivor, and escorting them back to your safe house. Whilst main story missions are walk here" and "kill that" goals. To me the lack of creativity really felt like it let the game down here.

Graphics wise; Dead Rising 2 is a game which has been out for close to five years now. Whilst at a glance the graphics look OK
date:
but if you get a closer look you can really tell the age of this title. Poor quality textures are the main culprit here. I can sort of forgive it as it is an open-world game though.

The main story right up to the ending had me intrigued the whole way through. Although some of the plot twists are kind of predictable if you pay attention; it was still enough to keep me interested. Sadly though the ending of the game really annoyed me. I don't want to spoil it for people but it kind of had an anticlimax feel to it which didn't leave a nice taste in my mouth afterwards.

Dead Rising 2 isn't exactly a difficult game
recommended: there are a couple QTE type actions you have to carry out when you are grabbed by a zombie
hoursPlayed: but personally I found the most difficult aspect of the game was to be finding weapons which don't completely break from durability loss after a couple of hits. Ammo for guns is few and far between so the majority of the time you are in melee - so ideally you need a couple of melee weapons each mission due to them breaking all the time. Towards the end of the game
voteText: if you managed to rescue a couple of survivors

The atmosphere in each of the levels actually really reminded me of Las Vegas; and if you have been there it will really feel like you are there in the game (even though you aren't there location wise in the story).\n\nA full playthrough of Dead Rising 2 with the majority of side quests being completed
column18: took me just over ten hours. I personally cannot see any reason why I would play through the single player story again as it's very linear and you cannot change the events that take place. The multiplayer is also pretty derelict too - at the time of writing this
column19: there are only 40 people in the game.\n\nTechnically I didn't have major game breaking issues; just a small gripe with the crazy amount of loading screens this game has. Literally every couple of minutes you get a loading screen
column20: whether it be for a cut scene
column23: I counted 7 loading screens in the space of 10 minutes at one point. For me
column24: that is unacceptable and I am surprised not many people actually picked up on it.\n\nIn conclusion; do I recommend Dead Rising 2? Personally I wouldn't recommend it at full price. For starters there are much better zombie games like this out there in the form of Dead Island. The game's length is too short for me - and all this being compounded by lack of multiplayer activity just makes this a single player game. So I cannot recommend Dead Rising 2 at full price; if you can get it for at least 50% off

reviewText: Bad\n\nLet me go further into detail with that thought. My own experience with this game was pretty poor. The game was glitchy, my character would constantly stop moving and restart running although I never let go of the key. My controller that works with all my other steam gamepad games did not work with this one. I find it annoying how there is no free play mode, and there is only the campaign, so I have to be on a timer constantly instead of just messing around and killing zombies like I wanted. The thing that set me off the absolute most though was the fact that I didn't notice that the game does not autosave. I played it for about four hours, and got decently far, and I was killed by a boss who kept attacking from off screen. After the game over screen, I saw an option to load..... from the very first bathroom in the game you save at. At this point I lost all investment. I could imagine someone else may be able to look past these things, and have fun with this game. My own experience however was a complete mess, and at this point, I don't want to give it another chance.

Featuring a new story, two online multiplayer modes (2-player co-op campaign and a 4-player â€œTV showâ€ themed Pay-Per-View event that pits humans against zombies), thousands of on-screen zombies and more, Dead Rising 2 takes zombie survival horror to a whole new level.\n\nAs Chuck Greene, you have 72 hours to save your infected daughter, clear your name and survive the hordes of hungry zombies before the military comes in and nukes the city. reviewText:
If you played Dead Rising 1, this game will be familiar, if you didn't, take a deep breath, because this is a different game from any other you will play.
It seems like a standard third person shooter/RPG with where you fight humans and zombies. But it's not, because of the timer system. Because of story reasons, you, Chuck Greene, participant of the tv show Terror Is Reality as a motorcycle pilot, have a total of 72 Hrs(Something like 14 hrs in real time, can't really remember though) to survive. During these 72 Hrs, you can save survivors and escort them back to your safehouse(Some survivors that were saved, I give you a sidequest, but not immediately), you can fight the psychopaths(The bosses) and there are events which you won't be informed and will start and end at their own, and there are the cases, which start at a determined time and end. If you miss the survivors, they die, if you miss the psychopaths, they disappear, and if you miss a single case, you fail at the story, although you can atill continue and finish the game.
The game takes place on the Canadian-Japanese view of Las Vegas, named here Fortune City, it's a great location, it is wide and full of clothing stores, tool stores, restaurants, fast foods, amusement spots and a giant open local that allows you to traverse it with your motorcycle.
Chuck Greene is a father, and needs to find Zombrex(Anti Zombie Infection Medicine) to his daughter Katey, if you don't apply the Zombrex on her, she dies and you fail the story.
Does it look fun? No. Is it fun? It depends. I had a great time, but you might not. First you need to endure the very clunky controls, and while the game gives you all the tools the get around(Dodge Roll, a Flying Kick for example), in the actual heat, the game doesn't play like it should, because there is this small delay that when you do something, it doesn't work right away.
The story is your fairly standard zombie conspiracy thing, but it still has great moments. Chuck is likable because he has a goal to protect his daughter and save the survivors, but he still has his brilliant moments of puns and word play.
The map is huge, and to unlock the best kind of shortcuts, you must progress the story and save survivors. Don't rely to much on the giant arrow that points to the objective, because usually the path isn't straightfoward, so the arrow will confuse it self, and saving the game is made on bathrooms or beds, the game does not have checkpoints, so if you die, back to the save spot.
The combat mainly consists of melee and unarmed, one button to attack, another to aim and throw/fire, and holding the attack button allows you to do an alternative attack(On some weapons). Using weapons found in the scenery like a baseball bat or a handgun is cool(Well the handgun and all other firearms with the exception of the Sniper Rifle sucks) but real deal is picking weapons and items and whatever to make combo weapons, like a spiked bat, flamethrower or a pair of boxing gloves with chef knives. You a combo card by leveling up, examining a poster of a movie, defeating a boss or even by saving survivors. If you somehow managed to combine a weapon without it's card, you will get half of the normal PP and you won't be able to do the alternative attack. You heal using food, some foods give you health normally, and you can cook and fry some food types to prevent then from rotting and make their heal factor bigger, if they rot however, they're worthless.
The game is arcady and not realistic, and expected lots of weird systems that don't make huge amount of sense. Like any good old RPG, you level up by killing, completing quest, taking down bosses, saving survivors, and heating a pan?
There is alot to do in the mall, and neat little things that make a difference, for example, if you take some ingredients to a blender you can make a juice that works like a buff(Spitfire allows you to you know, spitfire) and go to blenders often because these buffs are super useful.
The game can be experienced with a partner online, but if you're planning to actually do the campaign, I advise playing with a buddy that it's up to the task, because there are some co-op annoying stuff(Friendly Fire, leaving an area requires the two players together).
If it wasn't for the GFWL, this game would be better, but fear not, this game will have functionalities transferred to Steam Works this year.
It doesn't looks incredible, but it allows 2000 models if I recall at a time on the screen, and it's great, a really great and refreshing game best played with a buddy. I wished I could talk about the multiplayer versus that actually is the show Terror Is Reality, but no one plays :(

reviewText:
If you played Dead Rising 1, this game will be familiar, if you didn't, take a deep breath, because this is a different game from any other you will play.
It seems like a standard third person shooter/RPG with where you fight humans and zombies. But it's not, because of the timer system. Because of story reasons, you, Chuck Greene, participant of the tv show Terror Is Reality as a motorcycle pilot, have a total of 72 Hrs(Something like 14 hrs in real time, can't really remember though) to survive. During these 72 Hrs, you can save survivors and escort them back to your safehouse(Some survivors that were saved, I give you a sidequest, but not immediately), you can fight the psychopaths(The bosses) and there are events which you won't be informed and will start and end at their own, and there are the cases, which start at a determined time and end. If you miss the survivors, they die, if you miss the psychopaths, they disappear, and if you miss a single case, you fail at the story, although you can atill continue and finish the game.
The game takes place on the Canadian-Japanese view of Las Vegas, named here Fortune City, it's a great location, it is wide and full of clothing stores, tool stores, restaurants, fast foods, amusement spots and a giant open local that allows you to traverse it with your motorcycle.
Chuck Greene is a father, and needs to find Zombrex(Anti Zombie Infection Medicine) to his daughter Katey, if you don't apply the Zombrex on her, she dies and you fail the story.
Does it look fun? No. Is it fun? It depends. I had a great time, but you might not. First you need to endure the very clunky controls, and while the game gives you all the tools the get around(Dodge Roll, a Flying Kick for example), in the actual heat, the game doesn't play like it should, because there is this small delay that when you do something, it doesn't work right away.
The story is your fairly standard zombie conspiracy thing, but it still has great moments. Chuck is likable because he has a goal to protect his daughter and save the survivors, but he still has his brilliant moments of puns and word play.
The map is huge, and to unlock the best kind of shortcuts, you must progress the story and save survivors. Don't rely to much on the giant arrow that points to the objective, because usually the path isn't straightfoward, so the arrow will confuse it self, and saving the game is made on bathrooms or beds, the game does not have checkpoints, so if you die, back to the save spot.
The combat mainly consists of melee and unarmed, one button to attack, another to aim and throw/fire, and holding the attack button allows you to do an alternative attack(On some weapons). Using weapons found in the scenery like a baseball bat or a handgun is cool(Well the handgun and all other firearms with the exception of the Sniper Rifle sucks) but real deal is picking weapons and items and whatever to make combo weapons, like a spiked bat, flamethrower or a pair of boxing gloves with chef knives. You a combo card by leveling up, examining a poster of a movie, defeating a boss or even by saving survivors. If you somehow managed to combine a weapon without it's card, you will get half of the normal PP and you won't be able to do the alternative attack. You heal using food, some foods give you health normally, and you can cook and fry some food types to prevent then from rotting and make their heal factor bigger, if they rot however, they're worthless.
The game is arcady and not realistic, and expected lots of weird systems that don't make huge amount of sense. Like any good old RPG, you level up by killing, completing quest, taking down bosses, saving survivors, and heating a pan?
There is alot to do in the mall, and neat little things that make a difference, for example, if you take some ingredients to a blender you can make a juice that works like a buff(Spitfire allows you to you know, spitfire) and go to blenders often because these buffs are super useful.
The game can be experienced with a partner online, but if you're planning to actually do the campaign, I advise playing with a buddy that it's up to the task, because there are some co-op annoying stuff(Friendly Fire, leaving an area requires the two players together).
If it wasn't for the GFWL, this game would be better, but fear not, this game will have functionalities transferred to Steam Works this year.
It doesn't looks incredible, but it allows 2000 models if I recall at a time on the screen, and it's great, a really great and refreshing game best played with a buddy. I wished I could talk about the multiplayer versus that actually is the show Terror Is Reality, but no one plays :(

reviewText: Dead Rising 2 keeps the feel of the original while expanding the size of the map and looking much prettier. That's both good and bad; boss battles are still sprung on you unfairly and are incredibly annoying and frustrating, you'll still lose vast swathes of progress when you forget to go to the bathroom, and you're still going to be tearing your hair out on your first playthrough (especially if you want to save everyone). But it's the same good zombie fun, captures the original's feel very well, and expands on it with new content and features, more zombies, a bigger mall, lots of secrets to uncover, and multiplayer. Well worth the buy, especially if you've got a nice computer. (I've actually played way more hours than it shows, but it doesn't work for me on Steam.)

reviewText:
This port surprisingly works very smooth. The only flaws are Terror Is Reality still being bugged and not working. My friends and me found a work around and made a guide on how to set up multiplayer ranked so others can play.

The camera for the ramsterball (The hampsterball mini game in TiR) acted really funky for me and gave lots of motion sickness on my end which is rare specially since it never did on the console versions of the game. The game has very much replay value and it has a lot to offer specially in co-op online. I would suggest joining a group to find others ro play or else many will decline just because lots do not change the setting to private if they wish to play solo.

Remember to play co-op you need to get the radio and play through the zero chapter. Once you are in the safe room and exit for your first time via vents you will be able to invite friends.

reviewText: Welcome fellow ZOMBIE hunters to Dead Rising, 2. In this adventure you play as protagonist, motocross champion Charles Greene who prefers to be called chuck. Chuck participates in controversial games called â€œTerror is Realityâ€ in Fortune City, Nevada in hopes to win prize money to buy a drug called Zombrex which needs to be administered every 24 hours to young and out of place daughter, Katey. If she does not receive her injection she dies and turns into a ZOMBIE. Right after the 1st tournament a horde of ZOMBIES get loose all over the city & Chuck is forced into a position to search for Zombrex. During this time heâ€™ll come across other survivors to rescue & psychopaths to defeat. & all along the way must survive himself an overwhelming amount of Undead ZOMBIES. Single player or Co-Op, youâ€™ll be able to play thru again after the end to continue leveling and gain new weapons and combo weapons. The game offers a large range of individual stories and is very violent and dangerous.

When you get down to it, Dead Rising 2" is nothing more than some dev studio's gameplay concept testing that had AAA graphics wrapped around it.

Really.

Maybe it's my fault for not doing my homework more thoroughly
date: but what I thought I was going to get and what I actually got were very different things. I was primed for a roaring trek through a zombie-filled city
recommended: where dispatching the undead was hilarious fun and the key to success. The actual game (when I finally got it to work) is a boring loop of backtracking through the same
voteText: where killing zombies borders on being an afterthought.\n\nMaybe "Dead Rising 2" is supposed to be a parody of itself? I don't know. If there's a joke
helpfulPercent:
I'm not getting it.

Anyway.

column40: I thought to myself: "If this is going to be the whole game

reviewText:
A solid and fun game all around, made me laugh several times thanks to its macabre humour.
Technically complex and well made from animations to object and scenery variety.
It's rather difficult though, since the original gameplay is intended to last about 7 hours.
I ended up playing with a time changing trainer that multiplied the timer by 4. Thanks to this, the predetermined timeouts for game missions was delayed, and I could enjoy bashing zombies and exploring.

Only weak point are boss fights, which are quite a few and often one sided and stupidly arranged, so that you basically lose if you don't bring the right weapon.

Great cutscenes; zombie dismemberment; good audio and graphics. Certainly the best zombie game I've played.

reviewText: If you can find humor in the parts of the game that aren't so polished (cutscenes and voice acting, for the most part) you will enjoy DR2. Don't expect to finish the game on the first try - it's epic huge, and so detailed that you will probably spend at least the same amount of time killing zombies as you will exploring the world for items to craft and just looking around the massive (yet extremely detailed) environments. reviewText:
Dead Rising 2 is a great successor to the original Dead Rising. With a crafting system that allows players to create weapons out of random junk they find lying around to battle the hordes of zombies quite literally biting at your heels, is somewhat satisfying. The story itself being that it is a Capcom game could be taken with a grain of salt, but none the less it is engaging enough to want you to keep playing.

To be fair the PC port of this game I find to be the best version to play this game, what with the smoother frame rates, better graphics, and the option to use a controller or mouse and keyboard. Most people would think that mouse keyboard would fall under controller in a game like this but I actually though the port did a very good job tightening up the controls.

The multiplayer co-op this game features really nails in the enjoyment factor for this game, not only can you look like a psychopath but you can have a friend doing the same right alongside you. I would most certainly give this game a try especially with friends.

Great game, but poorly ported.

reviewText:
Killing zombies has always been fun to me, But whats more fun than slapping a zombie with a newspaper, or sticking a unicorn head with a bottle rocket attached to it on to a zombies head and watching him fly off, if that doesnt appeal to you then why kill zombies dressed like elvis, or dressed like a cross dresser. Cons:

reviewText:
Dumb & simple zombie killing fun.

Like the first game, weapons and health are generally all around you only this time around you can combine two specific items to make another weapon that's possibly cooler, sillier, practical, or a combination of a number of those. You can find out what item goes with what via Combo Cards which are unlocked through general progression of the game such as examining certain posters, leveling, defeating psychopaths, etc. You can combine items without the specific card however the item produced won't be as effective and rewarding. It's highly encouraging to produce the Combo Weapons because using them generally nets you PP for leveling and curiosity in how they'll work will become pretty high.

You're free to run around the world as you please (aside from some areas that can only unlocked from doing certain missions) though its criticized time limit makes a return so you only have so much time to get to doing the missions. If you stick to doing missions, not be as distracted, and perhaps if you're at a decent level it won't feel like it's rushing you to go do something so much. Even if you fail a task no matter how important and until the timer runs out or you choose to restart the story you're free to run around freely doing whatever. Restarting the specific save file's story allows you to keep your level, money, and Combo Cards for that next playthrough.

The plot & dialogue is full of cheese, especially with the psychopaths. I think it's for the better that that's the case.

There isn't much depth to the actual zombie killing aside from just having good weapons for the situation and the psychopath fights. The psychopaths can be extremely cheap in their own special way but at least for most of the fights you're free to leave and return to the area in case you don't feel ready for the boss fight.

The co-op's overall doable. A bit easier (if no lag is present) but adds enjoyment to the game. The money and level you've earned anywhere in a save file can be used in both single player and co-op where the only thing that doesn't carry over for either is the story if you're not hosting the game. The entire thing could have probably used an implemented in-game chat and give-item-to-partner feature as opposed to dropping or chucking the item for them to pick it up.

Fetch quests, escorts, and just messing around. Probably better with a controller since keys are unrebindable.

reviewText: Dead Rising 2 is easily high-ranked on my top 10 games of all time. This game is so much fun! Kicking zombies butts with knifes attached to boxing gloves, in a big â™¥â™¥â™¥ shopping mall is truly f**** amazing. The combo weapons are one of the main new features in this installment. Crazy combinations like a Power Drill+ Spear , Wheelchair+ Battery or even  SquirtGun+ Gasoline can cause total DESTRUCTION! But Sadly, the combinations are limited. You can see the different combinations by collecting combo cards, wich can be acquired by leveling up and many other ways. Despite the awesome gameplay, the story is also kinda great. You play as Chuck Greeene, a motocross champion who came with his  bitten daughter Katey, to Fortune City( a mix of shopping malls and casinos ) to participate in a reality tv show called ''Terror Is Reality'', in order to win some money to buy his daughter some doses of the highly expensive Zombrex. Then sudddenly, Zombies from the show are released, causing an outbreak in Fortune City. And if things werent bad enough, Chuck is claimed  by the medias, ''responsible'' for causing the outbreak. So basically the main goal of the story is to clear your name and escape Fortune City. One of the good things about this game, is that you are not in obligation to follow the story. This is great for younger players who wants to mess around and have some fun killing the zombies. However, one thing I dont like about Dead Rising 2 is the psychopaths/bosses. Some of them like the chef, are way too hard to defeat when you are low level and dont know the game very well. In my opinion, the most easy and proper way to defeat them, is by grabbing one or two snipers, a couple of orange juice/lobster and some magazines that increases the damage you inflict with guns. That is just boring for a boss battle. In  conclusion, if you are new to Deadrising , get this game. And if you are already familiar with the franchise, get Off The Record. In this version of DeadRising 2, Frank West ( Hero of the first Deadrising), is the main protagonist. The game also includes a Sandbox mode. A mode where you have no objectives and can do whatever you want! So go check it out! I rate DR2 8/10 for its zombie killing madness.

This port surprisingly works very smooth. The only flaws are Terror Is Reality still being bugged and not working. My friends and me found a work around and made a guide on how to set up multiplayer ranked so others can play.

The camera for the ramsterball (The hampsterball mini game in TiR) acted really funky for me and gave lots of motion sickness on my end which is rare specially since it never did on the console versions of the game. The game has very much replay value and it has a lot to offer specially in co-op online. I would suggest joining a group to find others ro play or else many will decline just because lots do not change the setting to private if they wish to play solo.

Remember to play co-op you need to get the radio and play through the zero chapter. Once you are in the safe room and exit for your first time via vents you will be able to invite friends.

reviewText: I'm quite disappointed in both Capcom and Steam in willfully releasing a game that is fundamentally flawed. No customer should be expected to jump through hoops to try and fix a game that should have been playable out of the box. Steam should especially be ashamed for distributing such a broken game. Would really like to ask for a refund. If you are looking at purchasing this game, please reconsider. It is BROKEN. Also please note, avoid any game that has a third person party packaged with it ie: GFWL. This will also cause you problems. This game could have been a great port, but apparently Capcom and Steam did not feel it necessary to invest the time to fully explore the flaws so prevalent in this game. The fixes" in the forums are poor excuses for solutions. In fact they are not solutions at all. Once again
date: a customer should not be expected to have to download
hoursPlayed: and download again to fix a game that should have been playable to start with. Also
voteText: full controller support is a flat out lie. I have an xbox 360 controller
helpfulPercent: and that option does NOT work.\n\nUpdated 3/20/15: Since the conversion to Steamworks
votesHelpful: Everything seems to be in working order. No longer am I having issues with non existent controller support
votesTotal: ridiculously lengthy loading times
votesFunny: endless GFWL "updating" messages
commentsCount: and just the general malaise associated with the DRM that should never have been spawned. I can now enjoy the zombie splattering madness that only Xbox players could. Cheers."
column16: December 8, 2013

reviewText: Excellent mindless fun. Butcher zombies with anything you can find lying around, or tape shizz together and unleash hell with combo weapons (I recommend the electric chair :-P). Excellent storyline with a fair amount of twists and turns. There's an extended/alternate Overtime" ending which only occurs if certain choices are made during the story. You don't even have to play the story
date: you can just spend your time chopping up rotten zombies and level up for when you restart the story. All key items and your level is transferred over when you restart the story which is a massive bonus in my opinion. You don't need to have played DR1 to enjoy this title.\n\n8/10"

reviewText: Picked this up on a sale for $5.  Very fun to play.  I love dead rising titles and I don't regret getting it on the PC.  Beautiful graphics still to this day.  1000X better then on the 360.  Worth even the 20$ IMO.  I see a lot of negitive feedback on the forums so be weary if it will run for you.  Smooth like butter for me.
